Award.AwardTitle: The Dynamics of Storm Tracks and Jets in the Atmosphere and Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to advance knowledge of the workings of midlatitude storm tracks and their relationship with large-scale westerly jets. Improved knowledge of the physical processes that drive jets and storm tracks will lead to better understand of the variability of the closely related surface temperature and precipitation fields. The three main research objectives are as below (i) to investigate the influence of surface Ekman pumping on the intensity of storm tracks; (ii) to examine the processes that drive jet variability; and (iii) to explore whether the eddy-multiple jet interactions in studies using highly idealized models of the atmosphere and ocean hold up in more realistic models of the atmosphere and ocean, respectively. The outcome from the eddy-resolving ocean model analysis is anticipated to help improve eddy flux parameterizations for coarse resolution ocean climate models.

In addition to training of graduate students, workshops for middle school teachers will be conducted. These workshops will blend science content and science pedagogy, providing teachers with implementation strategies for their classrooms. Thus the benefits to society are multi-faceted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of the project were to advance our knowledge of the workings of the midlatitude storm tracks and their relationship with larger scale circulation patterns such as the jet streams. Because storm tracks and jet streams are closely related to surface temperature and precipitation fields, it is important to understand physical processes that influence their strength and locations. Specifically, the proposed research sought to help answer questions in the following three topics: (1) PI’s previous modeling work showed that surface Ekman pumping, a process caused by frictional stress and Earth rotation, can, intensify mid-latitude storms. Does this process operate in the atmosphere? (2) Both observations and modeling show that atmospheric jets have been shifting poleward, especially in the Southern Hemisphere. Modeling efforts suggest that the increase in greenhouse gas loading in the atmosphere and ozone depletion can help account for poleward jet shift that has been occurring in the Southern Hemisphere. The second goal was to investigate if, and to what extent, the observed jet shift can be attributed to these two processes. (3) The third goal was to investigate how Southern Ocean’s meso-scale (on the order of 100 km length scale) eddies are related to oceanic jets and vertical motions.

The project successfully addressed all of the three questions. In addition, the PI and Co-PI performed additional follow-up studies. The outcome of the project was disseminated in 14 peer-review publications, scientific conferences, and workshops for middle and high school science teachers.

 

Some of the key findings from the project are summarized below:

 

By calculating energy of the storms and its conversion between the environment, the investigation found that the Ekman-driven dissipative energization process actually operates in nature. This can help to explain the long-standing question of why the observed storm track eddies have large amplitudes. The research also uncovered a new finding that during winter season, heat transport into the Arctic from the mid-latitudes and even from the tropics is carried out mostly by planetary-scale waves (wave lengths greater than ~ 10,000 km), rather than by typical mid-latitude cyclones which has smaller spatial scales. The investigation found that the planetary-scale waves, hence the heat transport into the Arctic, are often triggered by latent heat release associated with convective clouds over the tropical western Pacific Ocean. In other words, Arctic warming is favored during when tropical Pacific is in La-Niña-like conditions. One possible implication is that it may be an enhancement in the zonal localization of tropical convective heating (as in La-Niña-like conditions), rather than the overall tropical warming itself, that contributes to the winter Arctic warming.

 

There are a few outcomes from the investigation of the second research goal.  It demonstrated that cluster analyses can be used to perform attribution studies. The study also showed that the long-term, interdecadal wind trend is realized through changes in the frequency of occurrence of short time-scale processes (less than 10 days), and this provides a new avenue for identifying cause-and-effect and mechanisms for long-term climate variations and change. It has been known that in the Northern Hemisphere, the mid-latitude jet stream shifted northward up until mid-1990s, but this northward movement stopped afterwards. The outcome of the investigation suggests that more frequent La-Niña-like tropical Pacific condition trend to trigger northward jet shift, but since 1990s the melting of Arctic sea ice acted to halt the northward jet shift. The suggested mechanism involves interactions between troposphere and stratosphere through vertical propagation of planetary-scale waves and modulations in the polar vortex strength.

 

For the third research topic of this project, the PI and a student analyzed output from eddy-resolving ocean general circulation model. The outcome is that in the Indo-western Pacific Southern Ocean where the oceanic jets are oriented in the west-east direction, lateral flux of the eddy momentum plays an important role in driving and maintaining the jets. The investigation also found a previously unknown circulation feature that there is sinking motion on the equatorward flank of the jets and rising motion on the poleward flank of the jets. This jet-scale overturning circulations may play a role in the exchange of angular momentum and chemical substances across the entire depth of the ocean.

 

The project also helped educate two graduate students.
